captions.text: [music]
Strawberrykittlesful from Fayetfville USA asks
What are some of the differences between Korean students
and American/Canadian students
Is there anything that's weirder or different
and what about the school system?
So we thought about this for a long time,
even long before we got this question
because it's something that we're really interested in
because we were teachers both in Canada and Korea
so we really saw the differences between the students.
What we've noticed is that in North America
the goal is for students to be a unique person
to find out who you are, what you're good at
and to become different than other people
In the Korean system, it seems like being unique
or standing out from the crowd is looked down upon
Instead you should be trying to be a really good worker
and you find that out by studying really hard and getting really good grades
and in the Korean school system it seems that they're trying to find out
who is the best at studying hard, who is the best at memorizing
and who will as a result be the best worker.
Now don't get us wrong: there are definitely students
who are artistic and have creative opinions
but they are really strongly in the minority.
In North America it seems like you have an art class
or like a sports team or a shop class,
or something that really fits your personality
and you try to find something that really moulds into it
In Korea that really rarely ever happens.
So it's not that they don't have art class or sports teams
but it's a totally different approach than North America
In North America, while you're choosing and fighting hard
to get into something that you want to be good at
In Korea it's like you should do it, but you don't really have to like it
you don't really have to have enthusiasm because
really, a sports team isn't going to do anything for your career.
Now we see that this has a really big impact on student life in Korea
Students in Korea: their job is to be students
They study non stop.  They go to school until 4PM
and then they go to another school program.  They're studying all the time.
And even for the students that aren't interested in studying
they're just going through the motions,
they're not getting great grades, they're sleeping in class,
but they're going to school.
It's not like they drop out and get a part time job
That's very, very rare.
Now in North America, education isn't really that emphasized,
it's more about socializing.  You go to school to see your friends
you go to school for the basketball clubs, you have your part time jobs
but education isn't really the main focus as it is here in South Korea.
Now we're not saying that there aren't hard working students in North America.
Absolutely of course there are
But the difference is that they kind of end up being socialized as well
Not only are they good at school, but they're also part of a team
or they have a boyfriend at school or a girlfriend
or they have friends outside of their school.
It's not just like only studying non-stop.
While in Korea it seems like you must study all the time.
Now one interesting thing that we've noticed is that
South Korean kids seem to be a lot better behaved than North American kids
It seems like South Korean kids are working so hard nonstop
they're being pushed by their parents
pushed by their parents, and they're studying for their university exams
so that when they're finally out of school they're so happy like
OMG I'm so happy! I just want to talk to some friends!
Now in North America it seems that kids are really bored
they're not being pushed by their teachers.
Their parents don't really have that big of an impact
on their education life as well
so in North America kids are just like...meh!
And because of that meh, what happens is that kids
end up drinking, and being bored and destructive
like graffiti or breaking bus shelters
we never see that in Korea.  It's so bizarre!
I've never walked past a Korean pack of boys
and was worried that they might pick a fight with me for no reason.
While sometimes in North America I will have that worry,
like, bored highschool teenagers are gonna break stuff.
It seems like bored high school teenagers in Korea
give each other bike rides home.
You'll see two guys on a bike, one of them's on the back
they're, like, drinking soda
It seems to me like, not a boredom...I don't know!
It's like a group of Korean boys are like
We're free from class!  Let's enjoy this time while we can!
Let's look at some girls!
Let's, I don't know, play at the PC Room,
Let's play games together,
but not "Let's get drunk and beat somebody up and destroy stuff"
Now we're not saying that you're gonna go to North America
and you're gonna have high school students beat you up
burn your car down, get pregnant and do drugs in the process
But it seems like it's a lot more in the minority here in South Korea
than what we've noticed in North America.
Now altogether it seems that in North America they foster
more of a creative atmosphere for students
They let you socialize more and try to realize who you want to be
Sometimes, though, there's a negative byproduct from too much freedom
when kids get bored and they wind up getting destructive
with their lives and with other people as a result
In Korea, because it seems that they're not socializing as much
learning the ropes like through clubs and part time jobs and stuff like that
It seems like they're developed to be more like a worker
and another part that can happen is that
a lot of people can be suppressing their personalities
and suppressing their uniqueness
just to become part of a drone working crowd.
and I think that can be really sad.
But then the positive byproduct is that
you have a society in which people aren't as destructive and breaking things
they're more respectful and it's a lot safer here.
So I think the bottom line is that
we are personally very torn about what system is doing it right.
In Korea you're fostering respect for society,
people are working hard, they know how to push themselves
and they have a very innocent, normal high school career,
but then on the other side, North America
is experiencing personality.  You have love, you have loss,
freedom, socialization, and it changes who you are,
but then the problem is that you don't feel safe all the time there
While in Korea you can feel safe, but then
people can feel repressed and sad.
I don't know.  What do you do?
The balance between the two is really difficult
You gotta get something in the middleground, right?
Hardworking and lack of individuality
versus too much individuality and violence
So that's it for this TL;DR
if there's a question you want us to answer for next TL;DR
leave your question in the Google Moderator page.
Or, check out the question already asked,
and you can vote them up, or you can vote them down.
And don't forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs
Yes, because a lot of people don't realize that we have
two different channels for this.
That's right.  We have our bonus channel and we have our main channel.
What channel are we on now?
We're on our bonus channel.
We should do something additionally bonus.
Should we make a third channel?
Oooh.  OOOOHHHH!
Is it for Spudgy?
Spudgy channel!
I'd just sleep all day.  Ooh Spudgy channel.
GONG!
Sexy Music

title: Differences Between North American and South Korean Students

comments.text:
Pretty sure Korea also has one of the highest suicide rates. Did you

comments.text:
Hey Simon and Martina! Love your channel! I'm a teacher in the U.S. I had a 
few questions about education in South Korea. Does Korean have national 
standards? Where can I find them? Do all schools use the same curriculum or 
does each school choose a curriculum that they believe fits the standards?

Thank you. :3 (Spudge face)

Anne﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:

comments.text:
What you said about Americans.... TOTALLY TRUE. Or at least in my 
nieghborhood(school). Most of the students don't care about school and only 
go to hang out with friends. Really, teachers and parents don't give a 
f***. Like the parents focus on jobs too much and don't care how their 
child is doing in school. I even see people in class so excited over 
getting a C- or C+ for the final semester grade. I kinda live in a 
neighborhood where there's a lot of gangsters, thugs, ratchets, popular 
mean girls, ect. So I kinda wish I live in Korea, or a more formal school 
where people actually CARE about having a life after school. ﻿
comments.author: ashleyttran

comments.text:
I like how you guys put in effort to explore different perspectives. Thumbs

comments.author: jlwk55

comments.text:
To add to your point, as a Korean-American my Korean parents do think that 
being a "student" is considered a job. As my mom tells me, being a college 
student is my main priority right now. That is my "job" rather than 
focusing on other things..social life, boys and even other part time jobs 
are not as much of a concern as being a student. It is really cool that you 
guys have many points that I can relate to in my real life. I was born in 
the US and grew up in a very non-diverse town in NJ. I am very much 
immersed in American culture but I grew up in a Korean household. I would 
say I am 40% korean and 60% American. ﻿
comments.author: Sherry Jeong

comments.text:
Your videos validate how much of a mix I am between Korean and American. I 
was born in the US but grew up with immigrant Korean parents. ﻿
comments.author: Sherry Jeong

comments.text:
yeah we study but not all the time but no part time jobs yeah XD no drop 
outs thats looked down upon !﻿
comments.author: KpopManiac4Life

comments.text:
I definitely think it matters where in North America you are. I'm in the US 
and specifically I'm in New England. The collection of states in New 
England (these are Massachusetts, Vermont, Maine, Connecticut, Rhode 
Island; not so much New Hampshire lol... at least in my experience. They 
definitely have the "Live Free or Die" mentality) studying and such is more 
of a means to an end. There's a ton of pressure for students here to get 
into a good college and now-a-days colleges want people who have perfect 
grades, play 3 sports, volunteer in the community, have hobbies, and a part 
time job. One of my coworkers literally does all of that because she wants 
to get a nursing degree from Boston University. Now, she may want to be a 
nurse, but it's imperative that she get the degree from BU. I myself, don't 
have the best grades and I recently found out that I have two incurable 
illnesses(different story for another day) so I can't do all the backflips 
and acrobatics required to get into a big college. I'm going to go to a 
very small college in Florida and it's a non-traditional college. It's very 
new age and like you said, geared toward being social and creative as well 
as academic. So where I'm currently living, people go to school and go to 
college to make lots and lots of money someday. Again, this is pretty much 
just how it is for New England and I can't speak for many other places in 
N. America.﻿
comments.author: Serria Yisasia

comments.text:
I agree with you, although on a smaller scale, like county to county. And 
even then it not only depends on the school county but also the county or 
city the kid lives in and the values of the family. My family places a huge 
emphasis on school but the schools that I went to weren't in the best 
neighborhoods.
comments.author: penguin52692

comments.text: I think this was a brilliant commentary.﻿
comments.author: NewYorkCityViews

comments.text:
I also realize, I am gladly in America and prefer it be this way. I can't 
study end on end though I'd like to, because it causes me high stress 
ability. My school lets us be ourselves, and most destruction is like a kid 
dented his locker on accident. My school is filled with uniqueness that is 
highly appreciated. Reason why we should be able to be unique? Because 
everyone is different and it makes us so much happier that way, so why 
change the fact that we should be happy? ﻿
comments.author: Sara Yo

comments.text:
As an American, most in my school aren't as destructive as emphasized in 
such video, though, I admit most lack  hard workman-ship. I would prefer 
the Korean educational system by far. I am innocent, too, making me want to 
live there even more. ﻿
comments.author: Sara Yo

comments.text: I'm new. can someone please tell me what tl;dr stands for?﻿
comments.author: Amanda Hoang

comments.text: 'too long, didn't read' ;)
comments.author: Natalia Pietrzak

comments.text:
As an Asian American in the US, we have pressure from our parents to work 
really hard ESPECIALLY if you're in a school with a LOT of other Asians, 
who have similar values (you work hard, but so is everyone else!). The #1 
public high school in America is in our area, and as a magnet school, there 
are a disproportionate number of students who end up going to MIT or Ivy 
league colleges. I had a teacher in high school who also taught in East 
Asia, and while students in East Asia spend a lot more time in school, in 
the US, if you have AP, IB or other similar advanced classes, you end up 
with a LOT more homework than your East Asian school counterparts (spend 
less time in school= more work to do at home). Because of this, we spend 
just as long or longer (we end up with extremely time-consuming video 
projects Asian students usually don't have to do because of this 
"individualism") at home or after school, doing this homework, and 
effectively studying just like our Asian school counterparts. However, this 
obviously means that the students who aren't taking advanced courses and 
just overall don't feel the need to study, or the overall bad teenageres 
are going to get off school, leave school early, and spend it fooling 
around or causing trouble. So the level of education in America is 
completely dependent on your area, or even your specific school and whether 
you actually put work into your education. More affluent areas are going to 
have the top public schools in the nation (California, NYC, Texas, DC area, 
etc.) simply because they can pour money and resources (taxes) in to 
actually offer more advanced classes. ﻿
comments.author: wushunerd0

comments.text:
DC has one of the worst or it may even be number one with the worst public 
schooling systems in the nation. I believe NYC is getting better , but it 
is also bad. So just because those areas are affluent, you can't make a 
generalization that they get better schooling. DC also has a high rate of 
homelessness. Soo....... lol
comments.author: Judith Insilo

comments.text:
if we were to combine both extremes, humans would be better, creating a 
sense of hardworking and effort and taking school and learning seriously as 
a way to improve the world and not just to secure a big paycheck in the 
future would benefit us all, but it seems as if people are losing most of 
that enthusiasm and the goal of learning at school has been pretty much 
lost or deteriorated, but then it all comes down to parents to really guide 
their children and we seriously need more teachers who actually care about 
teaching the kids and not just focus on the ones that are already set for 
success﻿
comments.author: Irais M

comments.text:
true... very true.. I was raised in Canada but I came back to my mother 
country (south Korea) and it totally sucks... if you are good at art or 
other creative activity nobody notices, nobody cares. But if you get good 
grades in studying, other students get jealous and starts to terrorize you. 
They rip your notes and stuff. Also, the school actually make a list of 
student grades and put them up on the wall so everyone can see. Privacy is 
not at all respected. Sometimes the teachers even punch students or hit 
them. When I was 12 I was class president and my teacher slapped my back bc 
she thought I was being to energetic. OhOh and you can't even ask questions 
in class bc the freakin teachers think that you are trying to out smart 
them. As a Korean student i would proudly say KOREAN EDUCATION SUCKS﻿
comments.author: Amy Lee

comments.text:
Korean people think the school is for education and discipline not for 
socializing or creativity, because, the creativity in childhood such as 
crying, destroying, yelling, or arguing etc., is not worth to learn. You 
know how to exert those creativity without learning. Creativity is one of 
the basic things that god gave you. But obeying to your parents and 
teachers gives you lesson of patience for entire school life. Korean 
parents want their kids to learn patience through the entire school life 
before being fully grown before doing something. Because the world is not 
easy to live without patience.﻿
comments.author: Juheigh Hur

comments.text: I'm happy I'm in North America﻿
comments.author: Nora N.

comments.text:
I live in New York City and almost all of my peers (and myself before) feel 
the pressure to get good grades. Most of us want to get accepted into 
prestigious universities and, therefore, would try to mold ourselves based 
on what colleges expect/want from us. And because of that, most of us 
engage in extra-curricular activities so that it will look good on our 
college application/resume. ﻿
comments.author: Sophia S

comments.text:
In my opinion I don't like being forced to study and get good grades and I 
also don't like drugs and drunk people around my neighborhood ﻿
comments.author: Carmynn Z

comments.text:
No. North American students are way more behaving that SK students. SK 
students especially high-schoolers are so rude and arrogant. Some of them 
are even violent and scary. It's very hard to regulate gangs in SK schools. 
Once a police officer arrested a troublesome kid, the kid and his gang 
found the officer's child and bullied them. That's why teachers and police 
officers are reluctant to take care of these kids. ﻿
comments.author: 404 NOT FOUND

comments.text:
I have never in my life encountered gangs or gang violence in school. I go 
to a pretty ratchet public school and not one have I encountered that. It's 
all fair. It kinda goes like this:
1) Jumping/Bullying in groups makes you look weak.
2) You set a time and a place AFTER school or maybe even during to fight. 
Never sneak up on someone.
3) Most of the time, I see kids trying to hold back as much as possible 
from fighting anyways until someone gets in someones face. 
Academically, SK kids dominate us, but that whole or-deal with group 
bullying and ganging up on people and having gangs and factions is 
extremely ridiculous. I love Korean culture because of that sense of 
Brotherhood they have there, but I would never go to high school or 
anything in South Korea.
comments.author: Tianna  Smith

comments.text:
You must have never been to north america to say that. There are cops in 
front of every highschool and middle school where i live in america. I left 
middle school one day and there were students with guns shooting by the 
highschool across the street. Stuff in north american schools are worst
comments.author: kuroichan101

comments.text:
....that is childs play compared to what happens in North America... at 
least they didn't kill the kid or destroy/rob their house or beat the crap 
out of him
comments.author: shibbyxoxo

comments.text:
I must say sometimes I get a bit frustrated by the way we Americans are 
lumped together. I find that people tend to forget that we are a country 
made up of 50 states each carrying its own individual statistics. People 
take our education system as a complete joke, but in all honesty it all 
depends on where you live here. Not to say that there aren't highly 
intellectual schools in the south because there is, but statistics find 
that southern states have a much narrower education thus sprouting this 
idea that all we learn is how to be an "individual." I live in 
Massachusetts in which we go to school from 7am to 2pm and i'm greatly 
satisfied with my education. Not only are we taught that we do have 
individualistic talents, but we learn how to work and study hard too. 
Massachusetts’s fourth and eighth graders, for example, were second in the 
world in recent science tests only behind Singapore and sixth in 
mathematics. My high school gives us the opportunity to take college level 
courses from the time we're freshman to the time we're seniors to earn 
early credits and the curriculum is with out a doubt not easy. We've even 
had Chinese foreign exchange students come to learn about our advance 
placement courses and couldn't believe the amount of work we do. Our 
schools are some of the top ones in the world. In fact you could easily 
argue that if we were our own country we could easily place in the top five 
in the world and the same goes for other states as well. I understand that 
some of U.S states do fit into some of those stereotypes, but many states 
don't and I feel that people need to keep this in mind. Many of our schools 
have found a good balance between both studying and socializing and are 
certainly not intellectually inept as many seem to believe.﻿
comments.author: cookiesweetable

comments.text: I am from Massachusetts and here education is heavily emphasized.
comments.author: Serria Yisasia

comments.text:
+Mai Nhia Her Yes, and believe it or not I am well aware of that fact. I 
have no experience with any of those countries but i'm sure that they too 
are incredibly intelligent and also don't get the credit they deserve. 
However, I restate but once again that in all of my previous comments I was 
not referring to North America as a whole, but rather on America due to the 
sole fact that I live here and have direct experience. Which brings me back 
to the fact, that this video can't truly be a completely accurate 
description of North American education, since Simon and Martina don't have 
the experience to do so. If you are from one of said countries and would 
like to speak on their behalf then by all means do since I believe that I 
don't have the authority, exposure or involvement  to do so.
comments.author: cookiesweetable

comments.text:
North America is not just the U.S. There's Canada, Mexico, and Greenland as 
well.
comments.author: Mai Nhia Her

comments.text:
+Diam  Firstly I'm afraid I must call into question who are these Americans 
who can seemingly speak for every school in America? Just by reading the 
comments below it seems like these comments are coming from people with 
little to know teaching experience and some who don't even seem to live in 
America. My comments are directed to those ignorant people who simply 
comment "All Americans are dumb" or "American education is crap." Such 
ignorance can only lead me to believe that these people are hardly a 
creditable source. While I love Simon and Martina and respect their input, 
they also can't really considered complete reliable sources, seeing as; one 
they are Canadian to which I was referring to specifically to America and 
two other than their own high school experience they have not taught in 
America. As for other American teachers who may have taught in America and 
still have this opinion, unless they've taught in all 50 states to have a 
taste of what each education is like then once again I recapitulate the 
fact that it's pretty easy to discredit them. Also there are just as many 
studies stating that our high schoolers and middle schoolers are not as 
dumb as many outsiders like to believe. For example in an article from 
Huffington post writes; "According to a Trends in International Mathematics 
and Science Study (TIMSS) report on the math and science knowledge and 
skills of fourth and eighth graders around the world, if the state of 
Massachusetts were a country, its eighth graders would rank second in the 
world in science, behind only Singapore, and sixth in mathematics. Not only 
that, but according to the TIMSS report North Carolina was a top scorer on 
the fourth grade math exam, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, and 
Indiana were top scorers on the eighth grade math exam, Massachusetts and 
Colorado were high scorers on the eighth grade science exam, and the United 
States as a whole scored above the international average, 10th in science 
and 9th in math.
comments.author: cookiesweetable

comments.text:
+cookiesweetable There are countless studies that have been done on the 
matter. It wasn't an opinion I was stating when I said the only thing we 
have on them is our Universities, it was (according to those studies) a 
fact. But I'm sure if each state was counted as its own individual country 
that the numbers would look quite different.
I see where you're coming from though. I'd personally probably feel a bit 
more offended if these statements weren't coming from people from North 
America and who didn't have any teaching experience. But because they are I 
can't completely discredit them. There is some truth there.
comments.author: Diamond

comments.text:
+Diam  I completely understand where you are coming from. I have nothing 
but respect for them and their hard work and was certainly not trying to 
put it down in anyway. The point I was trying to get across was not that 
U.S education is superior, rather I was simply stating that it should also 
not be belittled, simply because we're not forced to stay in school from 
eight in the morning till ten at night. Also let's keep in mind its hard to 
compare the two countries in terms of test scores when the size of the 
countries is largely different. For example you may have the same 
concentration of kool-aid in two containers, but if one container is a pool 
while one is a glass of water, which will have a stronger taste? Naturally 
the one with less water to dilute it. Which once again brings me back to 
reiterate that if Massachusetts was its own country we would be ranked 
about fourth in the world only behind Korea and Japan, and that's without 
such a strict regimen in our schools. And this fact is not just considering 
universities but high schools and middle schools as well, so to say only 
our Universities are great is a statement that I must see as false. I 
admire the work Koreans put in. However it still frustrates me to have 
people see that i'm American and assume I don't work hard. I wake up a six 
in the morning go to school only to come home to study and do homework 
until 10, but of my own volition and many Americans are the same way as 
well. Not all of us decide to go to school for fun. It's not about being a 
"special snowflake" it's about having the choice to want to work hard or 
not.
comments.author: cookiesweetable

comments.text:
l think the reason why people tend to generalize when they talk about the 
US is because of the core differences in our society/culture. In the US 
it's culturally acceptable to  push young people to be unique individuals 
who are passionate about what they do. That "special snowflake" mindset 
doesn't really exist in South Korea, like at all. Many feel as though those 
cultural differences impacts our educational systems. 
School in South Korea was like nothing I've ever experienced before. The 
idea that the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few is 
practically shoved down your throat. There isn't a general acceptance of 
uniqueness and the students are studying until 10/11 pm. They don't have 
the same kind of Winter/Summer breaks that we do and I think that aids 
their ability to retain information. They're extremely tough and because of 
that their suicide rates among students is off the charts but that kind of 
environment, while I personally think is stifling, produces some of the 
most hard-working and determined young people I've ever seen. Of course 
there are kids like that all over the World but there's a reason why Korea 
is constantly ahead of us in terms of educational score performance. The 
only thing we really have on them is Universities.
comments.author: Diamond

comments.text:
I go to a charter high school in North America and I think we have an 
excellent combination of both. In a charter school you have to bust your 
tusch if you want to graduate high school and go on to attend college. I 
think we do have a negative of being overworked. If traditional North 
American education is creative but without enough emphasis on curriculum 
and studying, and Korean education is all about school work, then I would 
say the charter schools emphasize both with a negative of being spread to 
thin. We have to contend with AP classes and part time jobs at the same 
time. However I wouldn't choose any other option. I think maybe my school 
is closest to a medium because I have always had freedom to form my future, 
but I have a real sense of the type of person I want to become. So maybe 
something like my experience would work?﻿
comments.author: elizabeth freed

comments.text:
i think maybe the difference is that because of individuality, all of the 
pressure and pushing to achieve is put on students that choose to go into 
paths like that or show potential to be successful early on. like taking 8 
ap classes a year, and playing three sports, and being on the student 
government, and running clubs or a newspaper, and volunteering, and having 
a job, but then the students here that dont show potential early on are 
shoved under the rug as hopeless and then they get bored and cause trouble. 
korea seems to just expect everyone to keep up at least with school things. 
i mean when i was in high school, there was a massive divide between the 
regular students and the "smart" students. it was this huge thing where you 
were either an honor student with 50 extra curriculars, and all ap classes 
or you were "dumb and just not good at school" and shouldnt really bother. 
not that good of a system. it puts waay too much pressure on kids to just 
naturally be talented somehow or just forgets your existence all together.﻿

comments.author: Jay Martin

comments.text:
+Jay Martin You're absolutely right. It's easy for anyone, anywhere, to 
have an opinion. Here's an example: two teachers with extensive experience 
teaching in two different cultures would probably have a lot to say about 
the two said cultures they have spent years of their life living and 
working in.

You lost me on the 'privileged white' comment. Maybe if you yourself knew 
anything about the teaching profession, you'd know that teaching English as 
a second language is hardly a privileged line of work. The pay is minimal 
and the career opportunities are very limited. Why would 'privileged white' 
people fly half way across the world, for below average pay? They wouldn't.

If you're going to troll, at least have some respect for those who are 
busting their asses trying to teach our children and do what many of us 
wouldn't dream of doing. Teachers everywhere deserve our respect and 
admiration for the time and effort they put in to helping kids learn.

comments.text:
+Cheratomo And I would prefer those who are skilled as oppose to those who

comments.author: Blue Rose

comments.text:
+z90OoAluYsioNoO09z
You know, in thinking about it, the emphasis on individuality and 
personality does prepare Americans for working in their society, because a 
lot of your career success is based on how outgoing you are and whether 
you're a personality. (I.E. Chefs aren't known for their good food, but for 
their TV personalities - this happens with jobs all over America, and is 
part of the reason interviews are so important.) It's an extravert-based 
culture, so doing things this way forces introverts to learn how to 
constantly socialize and do group work, since that's what they'll have to 
do when they leave school (and how they'll get jobs - networking).
comments.author: Cheratomo

comments.text:
+z90OoAluYsioNoO09z
 I don't think individuality in America quite means "special snowflake/mary 
sue-ism." Having grown up there, it's more like "find what you're good at 
and stick with it, and if you're really good at it we'll reward you." The 
individuality comes from the fact that it doesn't have to be one specific 
thing. I may be really good at singing classical music and you may be 
really good at singing rock, and someone else is good at building robots 
and someone else at chemistry. But the emphasis is placed on discovering 
what we're good at instead of forcing people to be really good at one thing 
so that they'll know how to work when they don't want to. Both are 
important things to learn. I don't think one is better than the other.
Additionally, I don't think the reason Americans are entitled is because 
they're taught that they're "a special snowflake," but because of our 
materialistic culture, in which the focus is (when you're growing up) that 
people will give you what you want when you want it. Parents spoil kids 
with immediate gratification, so kids don't know that that's not how life 
works. Not to mention most Americans are extremely privileged, so they grow 
up thinking that what they want matters most. But this is a small minority, 
though it's our image to the world at large, kind of like how most people 
believe East Asians don't know how to "question authority" because they've 
grown up in a Confucian society, regardless of whether it's true.
I think it's possible we're both right, and we've just had very different 
experiences in the world. Neither one of our opinions have to be right, but 
I think it's important to move from the realm of stereotype (what we *think* 
certain countries do) to reality (what others can tell us their countries 
do).
comments.author: Cheratomo

comments.text:
+Cheratomo
True, but many awesome inventions, innovations and discoveries are done all 
over the world and almost especially during the last few years in some 
parts of Asia and Europe as they're on the fore front of technology more so 
then North America.
I think being creative is actually less about indivudiality in the "you're 
a special snowflake" sense and more about "There are many options out there 
and you can do whatever tickles your fancy". In short, at least with what 
I've seen and studied, the individuality as it were comes from options 
available to the person, not the person themselves. I don't think people 
are all unique as in super hero mary sue people, but that everyone has a 
set of skills and likes that vary quite a lot, but also nearly everyone has 
something in common. Like variances of colors, say I'm a cool ice blue 
based on things I like and am best at and someone else is a beautiful ocean 
blue/green based on things they like and are best at. We're both blue, but 
we're both a variation. It's not like I'm this amazing technicolor that 
very few people can see and I'm so special as I feel America in particular 
tries to tell it's kids. I think it creates this weird self-entitles all 
for one sorta mentality. It's why a lot of the ones I've met think the 
world owes them something.
comments.author: z90OoAluYsioNoO09z

comments.text:
It's an interesting question you ask, because I (personally) think that 
schooling prepares for both situations. In Korea, I think they're more 
prepared for what their society, culture, and parents expect of them. In 
America, I think kids are more ready to take the harsh realities of 
life-outside-of-high school when they're done with school, because they've 
had enough experience with loss and failure to step it up. Of course, it 
always depends on the person...
And there is something lost when you give up individuality. It's not just 
something that's good for the person, it's good for society. If everyone 
studies to be a doctor/lawyer like most parents want them to do, we miss 
out on new inventions, businesses, ideas, and the jobs and things most 
people would not want to do because they don't pay well or aren't 
respected, but are just as important.
comments.author: Cheratomo

comments.author: Jamie Ha

comments.text:
Yes, there's that idea that society says that you can be a jack of all 
trades and a master of non. You can be mediocre in a lot of things or be 
really good at everything. But the thing with being so specialized I think 
is that it gets repetitive, its bad for the soul, and you're missing out on 
other opportunities. Also you can never be perfect at anything and no 
matter how good you are at something, there will always be others who are 
better. This is why I like to diversify my abilities
comments.author: Antonio Maldonado

comments.text: undeniably true

comments.text:

daily looks like a paradise.
comments.author: Carlos Furtado

comments.text:
I'm Asian American and I'd really like to see you travel to North America 
and say those words in front of us, not behind a computer screen. Getting 
good grades doesn't mean everything. A lot of colleges and corporations 
look for "character". Besides being hard-working, they should be able to 
fix real problems, make deals, associate, and in general, socialize. 
Example: When you're a doctor, you don't sit quietly and do your job, you 
talk to the patient, tell them what they need to know or do.
comments.author: bubblegum1428

comments.text:

ours so you cant really use that as an example of a good student.
comments.author: RandomPerson066

comments.text:
Finland has the best education system in the world. They push out students 
that have advanced conceptual understanding (just as good as SK), social 
awareness and empathy, as well as self-reflection. In Finland, all 
education is flexible and subsidized, they foster strengths and improve 
weaknesses, encourage sharing and helping communally, and provide the 
skill-sets and tools to utilize our brains to their full potential. They 
are SK, but with kids who aren't depressed.
comments.author: Makentz
